Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Lewis Pair Polymerization: A Powerful Synthetic Strategy for Sustainable and Functional Polymers
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Division of Chemistry, is supporting Professor Eugene Chen from Colorado State University to conduct research to significantly expand the scope and utility of Lewis Pair Polymerization (LPP), especially for the synthesis of polymers from biomass-derived renewable feedstocks. Synthetic polymers are important components of a wide range of products including clothes, electronic devices, furniture, and household products. Professor Chen conducts research to develop novel catalysts and synthetic methods for the preparation of advance functional polymeric materials from biomass-derived renewable feedstocks. Important goals of this research are to develop efficient processes for the synthesis of polymers with desired properties and to reduce societal dependence on petroleum-based raw materials. This project also provides opportunities for teaching and training students in the use of a wide range of techniques important for catalyst development and polymer research.

Lewis pair polymerization is a powerful polymerization method, that was substantially developed in the Chen lab under support from the National Science Foundation. The specific objectives of this research are: 1) to develop stereoselective LPP for the synthesis of stereoregular or optically active chiral polymers from biomass-derived monomers; 2) to perform chemoselective LPP of biomass-based multi-vinyl monomers to yield functional polymers; and 3) to apply the LPP method for the synthesis of donor/acceptor (D/A) graft copolymers that are potentially useful for organic photovoltaic (OPV) applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lewis pair polymerization (LPP) is relatively a new polymerization method that exploits the synergy and cooperativity between the Lewis acid (LA) and Lewis base (LB) sites of a Lewis pair (LP), which can be employed as a frustrated LP (FLP), interacting LP, or classical Lewis adduct, to effect cooperative monomer activation as well as chain initiation, propagation, termination, and transfer events. The two major objectives of this project were 1) to develop the next generation LPP processes, aiming to enable the synthesis of advanced polymeric materials such as stereoregular, sustainable, and functional polymers or graft copolymers, and 2) to reduce societal dependence on petroleum-based raw materials. This research has potential to positively impact our society, as this work utilizes catalytic polymerization methods for advanced polymeric materials, two areas essential to modern life and the global economy.

Centering on the above central project objectives, our studies have yielded the following five significant project results. First, the first living LPP of conjugated polar alkenes such as methacrylates by a non-interacting, authentic FLP has finally been achieved with a FLP system based on a strongly nucleophilic N-heterocyclic olefin (NHO) LB and a sterically encumbered but modestly strong LA, MeAl(2,6-di-tert-butyl-4-methylphenoxide)2 [MeAl(BHT)2]. Second, the first living LPP of lactones, represented by δ-valerolactone (δ-VL) and ε-caprolactone (ε-CL), has been realized by a LP consisting of strong LA Al(C6F5)3 and an NHO LB, producing (co)polyesters with medium to high molecular weight (MW) (Mn up to 840 kg/mol) and a low dispersity Đ of 1.02, and without transesterification side reactions typically occurred in other types of polymerization methods for such copolymerization. Third, the first catalytic LPP of crotonates, b-substituted Michael acceptors that are difficult to polymerize by traditional methods or only dimerized by an LB (e.g., N-heterocyclic carbene, NHC) alone, has been achieved by the LPP strategy using LPs of an NHC or NHO LB and MeAl(BHT)2 LA. The LPP has also enabled the synthesis of poly(methyl crotonate) with high molecular weight and narrow dispersity. Fourth, the chemoselective LPP has been demonstrated by the LPP of renewable multivinyl-functionalized γ-butyrolactones by LPs consisting of an NHC LB and E(C6F5)3 (E = Al, B) LA. Fifth, the application of LPs and LPP in materials chemistry has been demonstrated by creating active layers of polymer solar cells through construction of brush polymers of donor?accepter dyads via adduct formation between a semiconducting polymeric LB polymer donor and all carbon LA C60 acceptor.

Key research findings of this study have been disseminated to the general public through comprehensive review articles, original research papers, and seminars or lectures before academic, industrial, and international audiences. The current NSF support resulted in the employment, training, and education of a total of nine graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, including trainees belonging to an underrepresented group, with technical skills needed to carry out modern research in chemical science.


Last Modified: 07/29/2019
Modified by: Eugene Y Chen
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Lewis pair polymerization (LPP) is relatively a new polymerization method that exploits the synergy and cooperativity between the Lewis acid (LA) and Lewis base (LB) sites of a Lewis pair (LP), which can be employed as a frustrated LP (FLP), interacting LP, or classical Lewis adduct, to effect cooperative monomer activation as well as chain initiation, propagation, termination, and transfer events. The two major objectives of this project were 1) to develop the next generation LPP processes, aiming to enable the synthesis of advanced polymeric materials such as stereoregular, sustainable, and functional polymers or graft copolymers, and 2) to reduce societal dependence on petroleum-based raw materials. This research has potential to positively impact our society, as this work utilizes catalytic polymerization methods for advanced polymeric materials, two areas essential to modern life and the global economy. Centering on the above central project objectives, our studies have yielded the following five significant project results. First, the first living LPP of conjugated polar alkenes such as methacrylates by a non-interacting, authentic FLP has finally been achieved with a FLP system based on a strongly nucleophilic N-heterocyclic olefin (NHO) LB and a sterically encumbered but modestly strong LA, MeAl(2,6-di-tert-butyl-4-methylphenoxide)2 [MeAl(BHT)2]. Second, the first living LPP of lactones, represented by δ-valerolactone (δ-VL) and ε-caprolactone (ε-CL), has been realized by a LP consisting of strong LA Al(C6F5)3 and an NHO LB, producing (co)polyesters with medium to high molecular weight (MW) (Mn up to 840 kg/mol) and a low dispersity Đ of 1.02, and without transesterification side reactions typically occurred in other types of polymerization methods for such copolymerization. Third, the first catalytic LPP of crotonates, b-substituted Michael acceptors that are difficult to polymerize by traditional methods or only dimerized by an LB (e.g., N-heterocyclic carbene, NHC) alone, has been achieved by the LPP strategy using LPs of an NHC or NHO LB and MeAl(BHT)2 LA. The LPP has also enabled the synthesis of poly(methyl crotonate) with high molecular weight and narrow dispersity. Fourth, the chemoselective LPP has been demonstrated by the LPP of renewable multivinyl-functionalized γ-butyrolactones by LPs consisting of an NHC LB and E(C6F5)3 (E = Al, B) LA. Fifth, the application of LPs and LPP in materials chemistry has been demonstrated by creating active layers of polymer solar cells through construction of brush polymers of donor?accepter dyads via adduct formation between a semiconducting polymeric LB polymer donor and all carbon LA C60 acceptor. Key research findings of this study have been disseminated to the general public through comprehensive review articles, original research papers, and seminars or lectures before academic, industrial, and international audiences. The current NSF support resulted in the employment, training, and education of a total of nine graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, including trainees belonging to an underrepresented group, with technical skills needed to carry out modern research in chemical science.
